title: Can a chord contain a note that isn't in that chord's scale? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes or no, depending on how you’re looking at it. If you’re harmonizing a tune, you’re building chords to support the melody. Some chords will be “native” to the key - and by that I mean that if you write them out in standard notation you won’t need any accidentals (other than those in your key signature). If you’re in the key of F, a C7 chord is “native”, because the notes C-E-G-Bb can all be written without an accidental - the B is flat in the key signature. A chord that isn’t native to your key would be an “outside” chord - if you wanted a G major chord in the key of F, you’d need an accidental (a natural) to write the B note. So if you’re in the key of F, a G major chord isn’t in the scale you’re harmonizing from. Now let’s go the other way. You’ve got a chord, and you’re trying to construct a scale. Let’s say the chord is Cmaj7#11, or C-E-G-B-F#. You can certainly construct a scale around that - C Lydian is one option (C-D-E-F#-G-A-B). Scales are a melodic construct, and chords are are a harmonic construct. So yes, you can have a chord that contains “non-melodic” notes (or notes outside your key), and no, you can’t form a chord that has no possible associated scale.

It sounds like you are asking whether all the chords you choose for your composition have to belong to the same key. The answer is a definite no. When one note in a chord is different from the home key, this could be a “secondary dominant” chord, or possibly a “borrowed chord (from a parallel mode).” An example of a secondary dominant here in the key of C: C E Am (where the E chord is the dominant of A minor, but Am IS in the key of C and E isn’t.) An example of a borrowed mode chord is from “It’s Been A Hard Day’s Night” by the Beatles, in the key of G: G C G F G (where the F contains an F natural, borrowed from G mixolydian mode, instead of the usual F sharp from G major). So go ahead and play whatever chords sound good to you. Many students have ears that are better than their sense of analysis, so there is probably a good explanation for just about any chord you pick, even though you don’t know what the explanation is. As to your second question, there is no rule to start on the I chord (tonic chord) nor finish on the I chord, as long as you establish what key you are in by some means. This is not a usual problem, so go ahead and write what seems proper to you.

A chord is actually a scale played in 3rds , so the C major chord can contain C E G B D F A , now we all relate differently as to why we would extend a chord in this way , and if all the above notes are played together there is a tension when we get to the F ( the 11th note) ( which corresponds to the 4th in the scale) . so we alter this note and make it an F# , this gives us the Lydian mode , this is familiar territory to jazz players , but to those starting out can be a little confusing , as in most of our listening we don’t encounter this principle , popular chart music almost never gets to chord extensions like this . The fact is all scales and chords are the same information as each other , that includes the frequently used jazz modes and altered scales ,

Of course you can play a chord of three notes, one of which is not in the current scale. Probably the most common example is the dominant of the dominant, refered to as the secondary dominant. For instance, in the key of C Major, play a D Major chord (containing an F#, obviously.) This chord resolves to a G Major chord ( the dominant in C Major) which in turn resolves to the tonic. And no, you certainly don’t need to start with a tonic chord. Why would you? And, while much tonal music ends on the tonic, it’s not uncommon to end on a dominant chord and that can sound fine if done properly.

Can a chord contain a note that isn't in that chord's scale? You mean like Cm7b5? or C#11? or even Cb9? Look at any jazz song book and you’ll see chords like this all over the place. They’re called “tension” chords, and they’re partially responsible for giving jazz its characteristic sound. A more mundane example would be the progression C, C7, F, G7 C. The C7 chord (C, E, G, Bb) contains a note (Bb) that’s not native to the C scale, but still sounds fine in context.

Yes, certainly. Just be aware that when you add tones to a chord that are outside of the chord harmony of the scale you are basing your music upon, then you need to consider whether you these external note to your Melody and/or lead improvisations. Once you know the rules you can intelligently break the rules.
You can do anything you want. The formal stuff is there to help you, but you shouldn’t feel restricted by it. When you use such a note in a chord, the chord becomes an Altered chord.
I don't know the answer to this but I asked my son who studies music and he said: Yes. For example, you can have a minor triad which use a note one half step lower than a note in the scale.

Absolutely. Brown Sugar by the Stones a great example. When you put a sus4 on the lV chord and don’t raise it, then that note is not technically in lV chord’s scale. A to E to D/Dsus4 for example. Sounds great nonetheless.

Listen to Bill Doggett's Hold It (Stevie Ray Vaughan filed the serial number off and called it “Scuttle Buttin”). The big fat chord is a dominant 7th with a sharp 9 on top sticking out like a purple thumb. The chord, if you're in A, has both a C#, quite natural for the key of A, AND a C; actually a B#. It's a sharp 9, not a minor third.
Of course it can. This has been done in music since….well…just about forever.
